text: As of my last knowledge update in January 2022, evidence suggests that sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors, particularly, have shown cardiovascular benefits, including a reduction in mortality, in adults with cardiovascular disease. Glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonists (GLP-1 RAs) have demonstrated cardiovascular safety and some reduction in major adverse cardiovascular events. Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors have shown cardiovascular safety but limited evidence for reducing mortality specifically. However, for the latest and most accurate information, it is advisable to consult recent clinical guidelines or medical literature as developments may have occurred since my last update in January 2022.

data.question: For adults with cardiovascular disease, how do dipeptidyl peptidase‐4 inhibitors, glucagon‐like peptide 1 receptor agonists and sodium‐glucose co‐transporter‐2 inhibitors compare in reducing mortality and adverse effects?
data.gold_answer: Reviewers found that for adults with cardiovascular disease, glucagon‐like peptide 1 receptor agonists (GLP‐1RA) and sodium‐glucose co‐transporter‐2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) reduced cardiovascular mortality (on average, 5 and 14 people difference per 1000 people, respectively) and all‐cause mortality (8 and 17 people difference per 1000 people) when compared with placebo (high‐certainty evidence for GLP‐1RA and moderate‐certainty evidence for SGLT2i). Although results did not reach statistical significance, GLP‐1RA may have reduced incidence of myocardial infarction (MI; 58 vs 65 per 1000 people) and stroke (26 vs 29 per 1000 people; moderate‐certainty evidence). SGLT2i reduced hospitalization for heart failure (78 vs 116 per 1000 people; high‐certainty evidence). As for adverse effects, moderate‐certainty evidence suggests that DPP4i increased risk of pancreatitis (5 vs 3 per 1000 people), but there was little to no difference between active treatment and placebo for any other adverse effect (worsening of renal function, hypoglycemia or fracture). Results of a network meta‐analysis (NMA) show that GLP1‐RA was ranked the most effective in terms of stroke and MI (high‐ to moderate‐certainty evidence), and SGLT2i the most effective in terms of mortality (moderate‐certainty evidence) and hospitalization for heart failure (high‐certainty evidence). SGLT2i was also ranked the safest treatment in terms of pancreatitis (moderate‐certainty evidence; event rates were very low in all groups) and worsening of renal function (low‐certainty evidence).

text:
Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (DPP4i), glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1RA), and sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) are all used for treating people with type 2 diabetes mellitus. They have been found to exert positive effects on patients with known cardiovascular disease (CVD) [2]. 

A network meta-analysis was conducted to systematically review the available evidence on the benefits and harms of DPP4i, GLP-1RA, and SGLT2i in people with established CVD [2]. The outcome measures of interest were CVD mortality, fatal and non-fatal myocardial infarction, fatal and non-fatal stroke, all-cause mortality, hospitalisation for heart failure (HF), and safety outcomes [2].

However, the specific comparison of outcomes among these different glucose-lowering drug classes is not provided in the search results. For a more detailed comparison, it would be best to refer to the full text of the studies [2][3][4].

text: Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (DPP4i), glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonists (GLP-1RA), and sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) have been studied for their effects on adults with cardiovascular disease. According to a network meta-analysis, both GLP-1RA and SGLT2i have been shown to reduce cardiovascular mortality, with SGLT2i being superior in reducing total and cardiovascular deaths. A study published in JAMA Network Open also found that GLP-1RA was associated with lower all-cause mortality compared to DPP-4 inhibitors. Another study concluded that GLP-1RA and SGLT-2i reduce the risk of major adverse cardiovascular events to a similar degree in patients with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Therefore, both GLP-1RA and SGLT2i appear to have favorable effects in reducing mortality and adverse effects in adults with cardiovascular disease compared to DPP4i[1][3][4][5].

data.question: What is the accuracy of combinations of menopausal status, ultrasound scan (USS), and biomarkers for the diagnosis of ovarian cancer (OC) in pre‐ and postmenopausal women with symptoms suspicious of OC?
data.gold_answer: For premenopausal women with symptoms suspicious of OC, ROMA, LR2, and ADNEX indices missed fewer OC, and of these tests, LR2 resulted in fewer wrong diagnoses. For postmenopausal women with symptoms suspicious of OC, ROMA, LR2, and ADNEX indices missed fewer OC, and of these tests, ROMA resulted in fewer wrong diagnoses. Reviewers evaluated the accuracy of different indices that combine menopausal status, USS, and biomarkers in pre‐ and postmenopausal women with symptoms suspicious of OC using histology in those who had undergone surgery, or clinical follow‐up in those with negative index test results, as the reference standard. For premenopausal women, the pooled sensitivity and specificity for each index test were 57% and 93% with RMI, 77% and 84% with ROMA, 83% and 90% with LR2, and 96% and 78% with ADNEX, respectively. Using the estimates of these index tests at an OC prevalence of 3%, the reviewers reported that for every 1000 premenopausal women tested, the average numbers of OC cases that would have been missed were 13 for RMI, 7 for ROMA, 5 for LR2, and 1 for ADNEX, and wrongly diagnosed women with OC would be 73 with RMI, 152 with ROMA, 93 with LR2, and 215 with ADNEX. For postmenopausal women, the pooled sensitivity and specificity for each index test were 78% and 85% for RMI, 90% and 82% for ROMA, 95% and 61% for LR2, and 98% and 55% for ADNEX, respectively. Using the estimates of these index tests at an OC prevalence of 3%, the reviewers reported that for every 1000 premenopausal women tested, the average number of OC cases that would have been missed were 6 with RMI, 3 with ROMA, 2 with LR2, and 1 with ADNEX, and wrongly diagnosed women with OC would be 142 with RMI, 179 with ROMA, 382 with LR2, and 437 with ADNEX.

data.author: Ciapponi, Agustín; Sharifan, Amin

text:
The accuracy of combinations of menopausal status, ultrasound scan (USS), and biomarkers for the diagnosis of ovarian cancer (OC) in pre‐ and postmenopausal women with symptoms suspicious of OC is as follows:

In premenopausal women, Risk of Ovarian Malignancy Algorithm (ROMA), IOTA Logistic Regression Model 2 (LR2) and Assessment of Different NEoplasias in the adneXa model (ADNEX) offer better sensitivity (fewer missed cancers), but for ROMA and ADNEX this is off-set by a decrease in specificity and increase in false positives [1].

In postmenopausal women, ROMA demonstrates a higher sensitivity and comparable specificity to Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) [1]. 

These tests evaluate the accuracy of a combination of menopausal status and USS findings (LR2 and ADNEX); the accuracy of a combination of menopausal status, USS findings and serum biomarker CA125 (RMI); and the accuracy of a combination of menopausal status and two serum biomarkers (CA125 and HE4) (ROMA) [5].

data.gold_answer: For premenopausal women with symptoms suspicious of OC, ROMA, LR2, and ADNEX indices missed fewer OC, and of these tests, LR2 resulted in fewer wrong diagnoses. For postmenopausal women with symptoms suspicious of OC, ROMA, LR2, and ADNEX indices missed fewer OC, and of these tests, ROMA resulted in fewer wrong diagnoses. Reviewers evaluated the accuracy of different indices that combine menopausal status, USS, and biomarkers in pre‐ and postmenopausal women with symptoms suspicious of OC using histology in those who had undergone surgery, or clinical follow‐up in those with negative index test results, as the reference standard. For postmenopausal women, the pooled sensitivity and specificity for each index test were 78% and 85% for RMI, 90% and 82% for ROMA, 95% and 61% for LR2, and 98% and 55% for ADNEX, respectively. Using the estimates of these index tests at an OC prevalence of 3%, the reviewers reported that for every 1000 premenopausal women tested, the average number of OC cases that would have been missed were 6 with RMI, 3 with ROMA, 2 with LR2, and 1 with ADNEX, and wrongly diagnosed women with OC would be 142 with RMI, 179 with ROMA, 382 with LR2, and 437 with ADNEX.

Reviewers evaluated the accuracy of different indices that combine menopausal status, USS, and biomarkers in pre‐ and postmenopausal women with symptoms suspicious of OC using histology in those who had undergone surgery, or clinical follow‐up in those with negative index test results, as the reference standard. For premenopausal women, the pooled sensitivity and specificity for each index test were 57% and 93% with RMI, 77% and 84% with ROMA, 83% and 90% with LR2, and 96% and 78% with ADNEX, respectively. Using the estimates of these index tests at an OC prevalence of 3%, the reviewers reported that for every 1000 premenopausal women tested, the average numbers of OC cases that would have been missed were 13 for RMI, 7 for ROMA, 5 for LR2, and 1 for ADNEX, and wrongly diagnosed women with OC would be 73 with RMI, 152 with ROMA, 93 with LR2, and 215 with ADNEX. For postmenopausal women, the pooled sensitivity and specificity for each index test were 78% and 85% for RMI, 90% and 82% for ROMA, 95% and 61% for LR2, and 98% and 55% for ADNEX, respectively. Using the estimates of these index tests at an OC prevalence of 3%, the reviewers reported that for every 1000 premenopausal women tested, the average number of OC cases that would have been missed were 6 with RMI, 3 with ROMA, 2 with LR2, and 1 with ADNEX, and wrongly diagnosed women with OC would be 142 with RMI, 179 with ROMA, 382 with LR2, and 437 with ADNEX.

text: In people presenting with chest trauma in the emergency department, chest ultrasonography is more sensitive than supine chest X-ray for diagnosing pneumothorax.

data.question: For people presenting with chest trauma in the emergency department, how does chest ultrasonography compare with supine chest X‐ray for the diagnosis of pneumothorax?
data.gold_answer: Using computed tomography or tube thoracostomy as the reference standard, reviewers compared the accuracy of chest ultrasonography and supine chest X‐ray for the diagnosis of pneumothorax in people presenting with chest trauma in the emergency department. Ultrasonography appears to be superior to X‐ray in terms of sensitivity (91% vs 47%), with similar specificities for the two methods. Variation in sensitivity impacts the tests' ability to rule out disease (ultrasonography produces fewer false‐negatives); on average, for every 100 people with a pneumothorax tested, at a prevalence of 28% to 36%, 3 would be missed with ultrasonography versus 15 to 19 with X‐ray. It is worth noting that reviewers did not classify any studies as being at low risk of bias for all five quality criteria assessed.

data.author: Burch, Jane; Mulhem, Elie

text:
Chest ultrasonography (CUS) has been found to be superior to supine chest X-ray (CXR) for diagnosing pneumothorax in people presenting with chest trauma in the emergency department [1][2][3][4]. This superiority holds regardless of the type of trauma, the operator of the CUS, or the type of CUS probe used [1][2]. The overall sensitivity of CUS is higher than that of supine CXR, while their specificities are similar [1][2]. 

In a theoretical scenario where CUS was used on a group of 100 patients where 30 (30%) have traumatic pneumothorax, then an estimated 28 would have a CUS result positive for pneumothorax and of these one (3.6%) would be incorrectly classified as having the pneumothorax (false positive); of the 72 patients with a result negative for pneumothorax, three (4.2%) would actually have a pneumothorax (false negative) [3].

On the other hand, if CXR was used on the same group of 100 patients, then an estimated 14 would have a CXR result positive for pneumothorax and of these none (0%) would be incorrectly classified as having the pneumothorax (false positive); of the 86 patients with a result negative for pneumothorax, 16 (18.6%) would actually have a pneumothorax (false negative) [3].

Therefore, CUS is a more accurate diagnostic tool for pneumothorax in trauma patients in the emergency department compared to supine CXR [1][2][3][4].

text: Negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) for adults with surgical wounds healing by primary closure may enhance wound healing by promoting tissue perfusion, reducing edema, and lowering infection risk.

data.question: What are the effects of negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) for adults with surgical wounds healing by primary closure?
data.gold_answer: RCT evidence is insufficient to permit any firm conclusions regarding the overall effectiveness and safety of NPWT in adults with a surgical wound. Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that probably fewer people developed a surgical site infection with NPWT than with a standard dressing, although the absolute numbers of people who benefited were low (on average, 68 vs 93 per 1000 people). However, NPWT had little to no effect on rates of mortality, dehiscence, reoperation, and readmission (low‐ to moderate‐certainty evidence). Rates of seroma and hematoma were similar between groups, while NPWT was associated with an increased risk of skin blisters (low‐ to very‐low certainty evidence). Results for pain were inconsistent across trials.

text: Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT) has been found to have positive effects on adults with surgical wounds healing by primary closure. The application of negative pressure reduces wound edema and improves local perfusion and lymphatic flow, thereby minimizing hematoma and seroma rates [1][4]. The improved perfusion and oxygenation facilitate quicker wound healing as well as minimize ischemic complications like flap necrosis  [1][4]. Therefore, NPWT can be an effective treatment for surgical wounds healing by primary closure. However, the specific effects can vary depending on the individual patient's condition and the nature of the wound. It is always recommended to consult with a healthcare professional for personalized medical advice.

data.author: Fowler, Cathryn; Weller, Carolina D

text: Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT) has been found to have several positive effects on surgical wounds healing by primary closure in adults. According to a study, NPWT significantly reduces drainage amount, increases skin perfusion, and increases tensile strength of the wound. It also has the tendency to promote collagen formation and reduce the risk of wound dehiscence, leading to improved wound healing and reduced risk of surgical site infections (SSIs) compared to standard dressings. NPWT creates a sealed environment, preventing or reducing bacterial entry to the wound, while removing blood and exudate from the wound, which contributes to its positive effects on wound healing. However, NPWT may increase the number of people with skin blistering after surgery, and the cost-effectiveness of NPWT depends on the type of surgery[1][2][4][5].

text: I don't have specific information on the accuracy of the World Health Organization (WHO) four-symptom screen for active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) in children with HIV. For the latest and most accurate data, please refer to recent studies or WHO guidelines on pediatric TB screening in children with HIV.

data.question: What is the accuracy of the World Health Organization (WHO) four‐symptom screen for active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) in children with HIV?
data.gold_answer: Compared with a composite reference standard in children with HIV screened for active pulmonary TB, moderate‐certainty evidence shows that the WHO four‐symptom screen (any one of current cough, fever, poor weight gain, or contact with a person with TB) probably has a sensitivity of approx. 61% (all results on average). Evidence for specificity is of low certainty and is estimated at 94%. Using these pooled estimates and a TB prevalence of 5%, reviewers reported that 57 children could be wrongly diagnosed with pulmonary TB and 19 cases of pulmonary TB could be missed for every 1000 children tested. Children with a missed diagnosis due to a false‐negative test are at high risk of TB‐associated complications. From a pretest probability of 5%, the probability of pulmonary TB would increase to ~35% after a positive test and would decrease to ~2% after a negative test. It is worth noting that one study conducted in South Africa in people up to 20 years of age (median 11 years) contributed 99% of the screens included in the analysis.

data.author: Burch, Jane; Taoum, Katia El

text:
The World Health Organization (WHO) four‐symptom screen for active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) in children with HIV has a pooled sensitivity of **61%** (95% CI 58% to 64%) and a pooled specificity of **94%** (95% CI 86% to 98%) [1]. This means that the test correctly identifies TB in 61% of children who have the disease, and correctly rules out TB in 94% of children who do not have the disease [1].

In a theoretical scenario where the WHO four‐symptom screen was used on a group of 1000 children with HIV where 88 (8.8%) have TB, then an estimated 88 would have a positive screen result for TB. Of these, 57 (65%) would not actually have TB (false positive). Of the 912 children with a negative screen result, 19 (2%) would actually have TB (false negative) [4].

Therefore, while the WHO four‐symptom screen has a high specificity, its sensitivity is relatively low, meaning it may miss a significant number of TB cases in children with HIV [1][4].

text: The benefits of thrombolysis for people with acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) include faster clot resolution and improved symptoms. However, it also poses risks of bleeding complications, and the decision should be carefully weighed based on individual patient factors and circumstances.

data.question: For people with acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT), what are the benefits and harms of thrombolysis?
data.gold_answer: Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that the incidence of post‐thrombotic syndrome would probably be lower with thrombolysis (377 vs 482 per 1000 people; all results on average) and complete clot lysis at 6 to 60 months would probably be higher (291 vs 120 per 1000 people) compared with placebo/no thrombolysis, but the number of people with bleeding complications at 1 month would probably be slightly higher (7 vs 3 per 1000 people); results for all three analyses were imprecise. Overall, thrombolysis may also improve the incidence of venous patency at 1 month (413 vs 167 per 1000 people) and complete clot lysis at 1 month (238 vs 50 per 1000 people). data.llm_model_prompt: Provide a concise answer for the following question: For people with acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT), what are the benefits and harms of thrombolysis?
data.author: Yadava, Mrinal

text:
Thrombolysis is a treatment method for acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) that involves breaking down the blood clot. The benefits and harms of this treatment are as follows:

**Benefits**:
1. Thrombolysis effectively dissolves the clot, leading to complete clot breakdown more often than with standard anticoagulant therapy [3].
2. It reduces post-thrombotic syndrome [5], which includes symptoms like leg pain, swelling, skin pigmentation, and leg ulcers [3].
3. It provides immediate symptom relief, prevents clinical deterioration and short-term mortality, and prevents long-term complications such as chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension [6].

**Harms**:
1. Thrombolysis increases the risk of major bleeding [5].
2. It has no effect on the risk of death, risk of a blood clot traveling to the lungs or brain (which can cause a stroke), or the risk of bleeding inside the skull [1].

Please note that patient factors such as the duration and location of the clot are key to achieving a successful balance of risk and benefit [4]. It's important to discuss these factors with a healthcare provider when considering thrombolysis for DVT.

data.author: Yadava, Mrinal

text: Thrombolysis for acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) has been found to increase the patency of veins and reduce the incidence of post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS) following proximal DVT by a third. However, it is associated with a small increased risk of bleeding. The potential benefits of thrombolysis include immediate symptom relief, prevention of clinical deterioration, and prevention of long-term complications such as chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension and PTS. Thrombolysis also improves the chance of successful clot breakdown and may prevent longer-term complications such as PTS. However, bleeding is a potential harm associated with thrombolysis, and the specific drug, dose, or method of administration used makes no difference to the rate of this adverse effect[1][2][4].

data.question: What is the accuracy of procalcitonin (PCT), C‐reactive protein (CRP), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) for the diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis in children?
data.gold_answer: When acute‐phase 99Tc‐dimercaptosuccinic acid scan (DMSA) was used within 30 days of a urinary tract infection (UTI) as the reference standard for the diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis in children, pooled estimates of sensitivity and specificity were 81% and 76% for PCT, 93% and 37% for CRP, and 83% and 57% for ESR, respectively. Based on these estimates and prevalence of 60%, the number of children wrongly diagnosed with acute pyelonephritis for every 1000 children tested would be 96 with PCT, 252 with CRP, and 172 with ESR. The number of children with acute pyelonephritis missed would be 114 with PCT, 42 with CRP, and 102 with ESR. Reviewers stated that heterogeneity between included studies was very high, reducing confidence in the pooled estimates. For information relating to the calculation and interpretation of sensitivity, specificity, normalized frequencies, and likelihood ratios, click here .

data.llm_model_prompt: Provide a concise answer for the following question: What is the accuracy of procalcitonin (PCT), C‐reactive protein (CRP), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) for the diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis in children?
data.author: Burch, Jane; Hodson, Elisabeth

text:
Procalcitonin (PCT), C‐reactive protein (CRP), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) are all sensitive tests for diagnosing acute pyelonephritis in children, with summary sensitivity values ranging from 86% to 95% [1]. However, they are not very specific, with summary specificity values ranging from 38% to 71% [1].

- **Procalcitonin (PCT)**: This test seems better suited for ruling in pyelonephritis, but the limited number of studies and the marked heterogeneity between studies prevent definitive conclusions [3].
- **C‐reactive protein (CRP)**: A low CRP value (< 20 mg/L) appears to be somewhat useful in ruling out pyelonephritis [3].
- **Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)**: This test does not appear to be sufficiently accurate to be helpful in differentiating children with cystitis from children with pyelonephritis [3].

At present, there is no compelling evidence to recommend the routine use of any of these tests in clinical practice [3]. It's important to consult with a healthcare provider for the most accurate diagnosis.

data.author: Burch, Jane; Hodson, Elisabeth

text: The accuracy of procalcitonin (PCT), C-reactive protein (CRP), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) for the diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis in children varies. According to a Cochrane review, the ESR test does not appear to be sufficiently accurate to differentiate children with cystitis from those with pyelonephritis. A low CRP value (<20 mg/L) appears to be somewhat useful in ruling out pyelonephritis, but there is unexplained heterogeneity in the data. The summary specificity values for procalcitonin, CRP, and ESR tests at certain cutoffs were 0.74, 0.39, and 0.48, respectively. Blood CRP, ESR, and WBC have been reported to have higher sensitivity and specificity for discriminating acute pyelonephritis among children with febrile urinary tract infection than urine culture. Therefore, while these biomarkers may have some utility, their accuracy for the diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis in children is not definitive and may vary depending on the specific context and cutoff values used[1][2].

text: The Xpert MTB/RIF test demonstrates high accuracy for the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) in high-risk adults, irrespective of signs and symptoms.

data.question: For high‐risk adults, what is the accuracy of Xpert MTB/RIF for the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) regardless of signs and symptoms?
data.gold_answer: For high‐risk adults (most individuals with HIV, miners, or prisoners; TB prevalence ranging from 2% to 31%), with or without symptoms, sensitivity of Xpert MTB/RIF for the diagnosis of pulmonary TB ranged from 33% to 100%, and specificity from 92% to 100%. Reviewers calculated pooled estimates of sensitivity and specificity for a range of subgroups. The non‐hospitalized high‐risk population of miners, prisoners, and household contacts of patients with TB had an overall sensitivity of 69.4% (low‐certainty evidence) and specificity of 98.8% (moderate‐certainty evidence). Sensitivity and specificity for people living with HIV were 61.8% and 98.9% overall (moderate‐ and high‐certainty evidence, respectively); estimates by prevalence of symptoms were 62.9% and 98.7% when ≥ 50% had symptoms, and 61.1% and 99.1% when < 50% had symptoms. On average, at a prevalence of 2% among non‐hospitalized people, 12 people could be wrongly diagnosed with pulmonary TB and 6 cases could be missed. At a prevalence of 10% among people with HIV (regardless of the proportion with symptoms), 9 people could be wrongly diagnosed with pulmonary TB and 38 cases could be missed. Positive likelihood ratios were high, with the probability of pulmonary TB increasing after a positive test, from 2% to 53% for non‐hospitalized people, and from 10% to 85% for people with HIV.

Positive likelihood ratios were high, with the probability of pulmonary TB increasing after a positive test, from 2% to 53% for non‐hospitalized people, and from 10% to 85% for people with HIV.

text: As of my last knowledge update in January 2022, remdesivir has shown limited benefits for people with asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection or mild COVID-19. It is generally reserved for severe cases. The decision to use remdesivir should be carefully considered, weighing potential benefits against any associated harms, and it's important to follow updated guidelines and research for the latest information on its use.

data.question: For people with asymptomatic SARS‐CoV‐2 infection or mild COVID‐19, what are the benefits and harms of remdesivir?
data.gold_answer: Moderate‐certainty evidence shows that for people with asymptomatic SARS‐CoV‐2 infection or mild COVID‐19, remdesivir probably results in fewer people experiencing clinical worsening within 28 days (18 vs 64 per 1000 people; all results on average) and in little to no difference in rates of any‐grade adverse events when compared with placebo or no treatment. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that fewer people may experience serious adverse events (18 vs 67 per 1000 people) with remdesivir than with placebo or no treatment. There were no deaths in either group up to day 28, and the evidence regarding clinical improvement up to day 14 was very uncertain. No trial reported quality of life.

data.author: Ciapponi, Agustín; Tort, Sera

text:
Remdesivir is a nucleotide prodrug of an adenosine analog that binds to the viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and inhibits viral replication by terminating RNA transcription prematurely [1]. It has demonstrated in vitro and in vivo activity against SARS-CoV-2 [1].

For people with asymptomatic SARS‐CoV‐2 infection or mild COVID‐19, the benefits and harms of remdesivir are as follows:

**Benefits**:
- Remdesivir probably reduces the risk of getting worse and being hospitalized [2].
- In nonhospitalized patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 who are at high risk of progressing to severe disease, remdesivir should be started within 7 days of symptom onset and administered for 3 days [1].
- The Panel’s recommendation for remdesivir is based on a Phase 3, randomized, placebo-controlled trial that reported high clinical efficacy in high-risk, nonhospitalized patients with COVID-19 who were unvaccinated [4].

**Harms**:
- Common reported side effects are nausea, vomiting, and headaches, as well as changes in blood tests [2].
- Remdesivir can cause gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea), elevated transaminase levels, an increase in prothrombin time without a change in the international normalized ratio, and hypersensitivity reactions [1].
- Remdesivir may need to be discontinued if a patient’s alanine transaminase (ALT) level increases to >10 times the upper limit of normal, and it should be discontinued if increases in ALT levels and signs or symptoms of liver inflammation are observed [1].

Please note that the effect of remdesivir could depend on how advanced the illness is when treatment begins [2]. It is always recommended to consult with a healthcare professional for medical advice.

[1] Remdesivir | COVID-19 Treatment Guidelines. https://www.covid19treatmentguidelines.nih.gov/therapies/antivirals-including-antibody-products/remdesivir/.
[2] Remdesivir to treat people with COVID-19 | Cochrane. https://www.cochrane.org/CD014962/HAEMATOL_remdesivir-treat-people-covid-19.
[3] Therapeutic Management of Nonhospitalized Adults With COVID-19. https://www.covid19treatmentguidelines.nih.gov/management/clinical-management-of-adults/nonhospitalized-adults--therapeutic-management/.
[4] Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) - BMJ Best Practice. https://bestpractice.bmj.com/topics/en-us/3000168/management-approach.

data.author: Ciapponi, Agustín; Tort, Sera

text: The benefits of remdesivir for people with asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection or mild COVID-19 are still under investigation. Some studies have suggested a potential mortality benefit and a reduction in the time to recovery with remdesivir treatment. However, the evidence is not definitive, and more research is needed to establish the benefits of remdesivir in this population. As for harms, remdesivir has been associated with potential adverse effects, including liver and kidney problems, as well as gastrointestinal and respiratory issues. The decision to use remdesivir should be carefully weighed against the potential benefits and risks, and it should be made in consultation with a healthcare provider[1][2][5].

text: Interventions that improve vaccination uptake among adolescents include school-based vaccination programs, healthcare provider recommendations, and public health campaigns targeting both adolescents and their parents.

data.question: Which interventions improve vaccination uptake among adolescents?
data.gold_answer: RCTs assessing a range of interventions to increase uptake of human papillomavirus (HPV) and hepatitis B vaccines provide inconclusive evidence as to whether these interventions were more effective than usual care; the range of interventions assessed and inconsistencies depending on the population and vaccine assessed mean that no firm conclusions can be drawn. High‐certainty evidence from the USA and from Sweden shows that uptake of HPV vaccination among adolescents is higher with health education than with usual practice such as health promotion media presentations (363 vs 254 per 1000 adolescents; all results on average). However, participants who received complex health education (in the form of a four‐lesson multi‐component intervention) had slightly lower rates of hepatitis B vaccine uptake compared with those who received standard government information brochures (738 vs 756 per 1000 adolescents; moderate‐certainty evidence). Low‐certainty evidence from the United Kingdom suggests that financial incentives given to participants on completion of the HPV vaccine course resulted in better vaccine uptake than invitations provided with information leaflets (284 vs 196 per 1000 adolescents). Very low‐certainty evidence from the USA suggests that financial incentives in addition to health education may result in better uptake of hepatitis B vaccination than usual care (623 vs 451 per 1000 adolescents); however, the analysis was underpowered, so differences between groups did not reach statistical significance. Moderate‐certainty evidence from the USA shows that a policy for mandatory vaccination resulted in better uptake of hepatitis B vaccination (728 vs 186 per 1000 adolescents). In schools In Tanzania, making the mandatory vaccination class‐based rather than age‐based resulted in better HPV vaccine uptake (787 vs 721 per 1000 adolescents). A single RCT assessing provider prompts compared with usual care could not draw conclusions, as key outcomes were not assessed. Low‐certainty evidence suggests that HPV vaccine uptake was higher with multi‐component provider and parent interventions when compared with usual care, but differences between groups did not reach statistical significance and the analysis was underpowered, so no conclusions can be drawn. No RCTs assessed effects of interventions on vaccine‐preventable diseases or on vaccine‐related adverse events.

data.author: Bhat, Smitha

text:
Several interventions have been found to improve vaccination uptake among adolescents:

1. **Educational Interventions**: Providing vaccination information and education to adolescents and their parents can increase the uptake of vaccines such as the HPV vaccine [1][2].

2. **Reminders**: Sending reminders about when vaccines are due can increase overall vaccination coverage [1].

3. **Provider-Directed Interventions**: Interventions for healthcare providers, such as information, reminders, or feedback about their practice, can improve the uptake of vaccination in adolescents [1].

4. **Financial Incentives**: Offering gifts or financial incentives to adolescents can increase the uptake of vaccines like the HPV vaccine [1][2].

5. **Legislation**: Passing laws that require adolescents to be vaccinated to attend school can substantially increase the uptake of vaccines [2].

6. **Multilevel Interventions**: These interventions, which involve multiple strategies, may also improve vaccination coverage [1].

Please note that the effectiveness of these interventions can vary depending on the specific context and population. It's always recommended to consult with a healthcare professional for medical advice.

[1] Interventions to Improve Immunization Coverage Among Children and .... https://publications.aap.org/pediatrics/article/149/Supplement%206/e2021053852D/186948/Interventions-to-Improve-Immunization-Coverage.
[2] Improving vaccination uptake among adolescents | Cochrane. https://www.cochrane.org/CD011895/EPOC_improving-vaccination-uptake-among-adolescents.
[3] Improving vaccination uptake among adolescents (Review). https://abstracts.cochrane.org/2020-abstracts/improving-vaccination-uptake-among-adolescents-review.
[4] undefined. https://doi.org/10.1542/peds.2021-053852D.

data.author: Bhat, Smitha

text: Various strategies have been evaluated to improve adolescent vaccination uptake, including health education, financial incentives, mandatory vaccination, and class-based school vaccine delivery. However, most of the evidence is of low to moderate certainty. A multi-component provider intervention, including an education session, repeated contacts, individualized feedback, and incentives, probably improves the uptake of HPV vaccine compared to usual practice. Additionally, class-based school vaccination strategies and recipient-oriented interventions, such as education, reminders, incentives, and mandatory vaccination, have been proposed to enhance vaccination uptake among adolescents. Further research is needed to enhance adolescent vaccination uptake[1][3].
